Description: Terracotta female figure. Naked pregnant woman, squatting with legs raised on each side to expose her genitals: she holds her left leg up with her left hand, but both her left arm and her lower leg are lost; she indicates her pubic area with her right hand. She looks down to her right; her hair has a centre parting, and she wears bracelets and armlets on her right arm. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt with traces of a white dressing; there are minute touches remaining of pink-buff paint on the flesh and dark-red paint on the hair.
Curator's comments: This example is from the same mould as NA496 from Naukratis in Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology, both were probably made in Naukratis. GR1973,0501.68 and GR1973,0501.69, GR1965,0930.974 , GR1886,0401.1452 GR1973,0501.68 and seems to be from the same mould as figure NA516 (Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology) and E.104.1914 (Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum). Naukratis is the most likely find spot and production place for these objects, based on the style, fabric, date of the figures and history of the Greece and Rome department’s holdings of Egyptian material (73% are from Naukratis). Similar parallels dated from the second century BC to first century AD, from Naukratis (Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, E.104.1914; = Ashton et al. 2004: no. 92). The Hellenistic period is also suggested (Montserrat 1996, pl. 23; and Dunand 1990, no. 562; and Grmek and Gourevitch 1998, 167, fig. 115). Petrie Museum UC33447, from Memphis; and parallels from a Ptolemaic context at Akoris (Tsujimura 1999, 16, fig. 12:6). Also a very similar Hellenistic terracotta from the Cyrenaica, regarded as based upon Egyptian examples (Burn and Higgins 2001, no. 2777). Ashton, S.-A., Buttrey, T. and Popescu, A. 2004. Roman Egyptomania, London. Burn, L., Higgins, R., Catalogue of Greek Terracottas in the British Museum, III, London. Dunand, F. 1990, Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte, Paris. Montserrat, D. 1996. Sex and society in Greco-Roman Egypt, London. Grmek, M. and Gourevitch, D. 1998. Les maladies dans l’art antique, Poiters. Tsujimura, S. 1999, in Kawanishi, H. and Tsujimursa, S. (eds), Akoris 1998. Preliminary Report, Ibaraki.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3135)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.470) (Phase 1)
Condition: Her right leg is missing from midthigh, and all the back has gone. Left arm and left lower leg gone.
